sn2.25:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā bhikkhū, kosalesu viharanti himavantapasse araññakuṭikāya uddhatā unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā muṭṭhassatino asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā pākatindriyā.
sn2.25:1.2.eng: At one time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands, in a wilderness hut on the slopes of the Himalayas. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
sn2.25:1.2.comm: Normally kuṭikā is understood as a diminutive of kuṭi, hence “little hut”. But here several mendicants are staying (as at Ud 4.2:1.3), while elsewhere the Buddha stayed in one while at the Jetavana (DN 14:1.1.2). More likely the suffix here does not change the meaning of kuṭi.

sn2.25:2.1.pli: Atha kho jantu devaputto tadahuposathe pannarase yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.25:2.1.eng: Then on the fifteenth day sabbath the godling Jantu went up to those mendicants and addressed them in verse:
sn2.25:2.1.comm: The deity Jantu (“personage”, “man”, “offspring”) cannot be identified.

sn2.25:3.5.eng: Knowing that the world was impermanent

sn2.25:3.6.eng: they made an end of suffering.

sn2.25:4.1.eng: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,

sn2.25:4.3.eng: They eat and eat and then lie down,

sn2.25:4.4.eng: passed out in the homes of others.
sn2.25:4.4.comm: Monks falling asleep inappropriately is addressed in the Vinaya (Bu Pc 5, Bu Ss 1:2.1.1, Kd 8:16.1.1; see also Kd 1:7.2.2). | Mucchita in Pali usually means “infatuated, besotted”, but the normal meaning of Sanskrit mūrchita is “fainted, passed out”.

sn2.25:5.1.eng: Having raised my joined palms to the Saṅgha,

sn2.25:5.2.eng: I speak here only about certain people.

sn2.25:5.4.eng: just like those who have passed away.

sn2.26:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rohitasso devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.26:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Rohitassa said to the Buddha:
sn2.26:1.2.comm: Rohitassa (“red horse”) is Agni in his manifestation as the swift sunbeam, breaking over the mountains and flashing across the sky. Agni was he of red horses (rohidaśva, Rig Veda 1.45.2, 4.1.8, 8.43.16, 10.7.4, 10.98.9; see 2.10.2). This can mean the tongues of the ritual fire whose message is speedily conveyed to the gods, but especially the “ruddy steed” swift as the wind (aruṣā rohitā, 1.94.10), the “red horses of the dawn” (aruṇebhir aśvair, Rig Veda 1.113.14, see 4.52.2, 6.65.2, 7.75.6). The current Sutta seems to draw on the conception of Rohita in Atharvaveda 13, glorifying Agni as the Sun, who “arrives in a flash” (13.2.15), “swift” (13.2.2), “rushing” (13.2.19), “traversing the sky” (13.2.22), radiating as far as worlds extend (13.2.42, 13.2.10, 13.1.16), racing over the world never letting his thought stray (13.2.15). The “Sun’s bay horses” (sūryasyāśvā harayaḥ, 13.1.24) are seven ruddy steeds who carry it, spreading out its rays (13.2.4, 13.3.16).

sn2.26:1.3.pli: “yattha nu kho, bhante, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, sakkā nu kho so, bhante, gamanena lokassa anto ñātuṃ vā daṭṭhuṃ vā pāpuṇituṃ vā”ti?
sn2.26:1.3.eng: “Sir, is it possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn?”

sn2.26:1.4.pli: “Yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī”ti.
sn2.26:1.4.eng: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.”

sn2.26:2.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

sn2.26:2.3.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’ti.

sn2.26:3.1.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, rohitasso nāma isi ahosiṃ bhojaputto iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo.
sn2.26:3.1.eng: Once upon a time, I was a seer called Rohitassa, son of the benefactors. I was a sky-walker with psychic powers.
sn2.26:3.1.comm: The coming of the dawn was greeted with priestly gifts offered by benefactors (bhoja). These benefactors may be the Aṅgīrasas, shining poets who ushered in the dawn (RV 3.53.7), or else the Aśvins, horse deities driving the Sun’s chariot and close with the Sun’s daughter (4.43.2, 8.8.2), or the dawns themselves (4.51.3, 7.79.3, 8.25.21).

sn2.26:3.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo javo ahosi; seyyathāpi nāma daḷhadhammā dhanuggaho susikkhito katahattho katayoggo katūpāsano lahukena asanena appakasireneva tiriyaṃ tālacchāyaṃ atipāteyya.
sn2.26:3.2.eng: I was as fast as a light arrow easily shot across the shadow of a palm tree by a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow.
sn2.26:3.2.comm: Taught as a parable by the Buddha to two brahmin cosmologists (lokāyatikā) at AN 9.38:4.1.

sn2.26:3.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpo padavītihāro ahosi; seyyathāpi nāma puratthimā samuddā pacchimo samuddo.
sn2.26:3.3.eng: My stride was such that it could span from the eastern ocean to the western ocean.
sn2.26:3.3.comm: It has been pointed out that a swift arrow can fly at 250 f/s, which would take 0.008 seconds to cross the width of a palm trunk of two feet. India ocean to ocean is about 2400 km. To cross it in 0.008 seconds would require a velocity of around 300,000 km/s—the speed of light.

sn2.26:3.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, evarūpaṃ icchāgataṃ uppajji:

sn2.26:3.5.eng: ‘I will reach the end of the world by traveling.’

sn2.26:3.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, bhante, evarūpena javena samannāgato evarūpena ca padavītihārena, aññatreva asitapītakhāyitasāyitā aññatra uccārapassāvakammā aññatra niddākilamathapaṭivinodanā vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī vassasataṃ gantvā appatvāva lokassa antaṃ antarāva kālaṅkato.
sn2.26:3.6.eng: Having such speed and stride, I traveled for my whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—and I passed away along the way, never reaching the end of the world.

sn2.26:4.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

sn2.26:4.3.pli: ‘yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmī’”ti.
sn2.26:4.3.eng: ‘Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.’”

sn2.26:5.1.pli: “Na kho panāhaṃ, āvuso, appatvā lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmi.
sn2.26:5.1.eng: “But Reverend, I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.

sn2.26:5.2.pli: Api ca khvāhaṃ, āvuso, imasmiṃyeva byāmamatte kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca paññapemi lokasamudayañca lokanirodhañca lokanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadanti.
sn2.26:5.2.eng: For it is in this fathom-long carcass with its perception and mind that I describe the world, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
sn2.26:5.2.comm: This echoes Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.5.14 and 7.1.1.37, where the fire altar is measured out as a fathom (vyāmamātra) for this is the length of a human. The altar and the human person encompass the whole world.

sn2.26:6.1.eng: The end of the world can never

sn2.26:6.3.eng: But without reaching the end of the world,

sn2.26:7.1.eng: So an intelligent person, understanding the world,

sn2.26:7.2.eng: has completed the spiritual journey <j>and gone to the end of the world.

sn2.26:7.3.eng: Assuaged, knowing the end of the world,

sn2.26:7.4.eng: they do not hope for this world or the next.”

sn2.27:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho nando devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.27:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Nanda spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.27:1.1.comm: Nanda (“delight”) is a common name. These verses are also at SN 1.4.

sn2.27:2.2.eng: the stages of life leave us one by one.

sn2.27:2.4.eng: do good deeds that bring you joy.”

sn2.27:3.2.eng: the stages of life leave us one by one.

sn2.27:3.4.eng: a seeker of peace would drop the world’s bait.”

sn2.28:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho nandivisālo devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.28:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Nandivisāla addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.28:1.1.comm: At Bu Pc 2 = Ja 28 we meet an ox of this name. Perhaps the virtuous beast was reborn as a god, still concerned with pulling laden carts. Pāṇini lists it as a name, but no such individual has been identified in Sanskrit.

sn2.28:2.1.eng: “Four are its wheels, and nine its doors;
sn2.28:2.1.comm: These verses are also at SN 1.29; see notes there.

sn2.28:2.2.eng: it’s stuffed full, bound with greed,

sn2.28:2.4.eng: Great hero, how will I keep going?”

sn2.28:3.3.eng: and having plucked out craving, root and all:

sn2.28:3.4.eng: that’s how you will keep going.”

sn2.29:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn2.29:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn2.29:2.1.pli: “Kassa hi nāma, bhante, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa āyasmā sāriputto na rucceyya?
sn2.29:2.1.eng: “Sir, who on earth would not endorse Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?

sn2.29:2.18.pli: Kassa hi nāma, bhante, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa āyasmā sāriputto na rucceyyā”ti?
sn2.29:2.18.eng: Who on earth would not endorse Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”

sn2.29:3.1.eng: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!

sn2.29:3.2.pli: Kassa hi nāma, ānanda, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa sāriputto na rucceyya?
sn2.29:3.2.eng: Who on earth would not endorse Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”

sn2.29:3.3.eng: And the Buddha repeated all of Ānanda’s terms of praise.

sn2.29:3.19.pli: Kassa hi nāma, ānanda, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa sāriputto na rucceyyā”ti?

sn2.29:4.1.pli: Atha kho susimo devaputto āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne mahatiyā devaputtaparisāya parivuto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho susimo devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.29:4.1.eng: While this praise of Sāriputta was being spoken, the godling Susīma approached the Buddha, escorted by a large assembly of godlings. He bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
sn2.29:4.1.comm: This is perhaps the same godling Susīma who was too lazy to follow Sakka's orders (SN 11.2). Another Susīma is a renunciate at SN 12.70.

sn2.29:5.1.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

sn2.29:5.2.pli: Kassa hi nāma, bhante, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa āyasmā sāriputto na rucceyya?
sn2.29:5.2.eng: Who on earth would not endorse Venerable Sāriputta unless they’re a fool, a hater, delusional, or mentally deranged?”

sn2.29:5.3.eng: And he too repeated all the terms of praise of Sāriputta, adding,

sn2.29:5.4.pli: Mahāpañño, bhante, puthupañño, bhante, hāsapañño, bhante, javanapañño, bhante, tikkhapañño, bhante, nibbedhikapañño, bhante, appiccho, bhante, santuṭṭho, bhante, pavivitto, bhante, asaṃsaṭṭho, bhante, āraddhavīriyo, bhante, vattā, bhante, vacanakkhamo, bhante, codako, bhante, pāpagarahī, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto.

sn2.29:5.5.pli: Kassa hi nāma, bhante, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa āyasmā sāriputto na rucceyya?

sn2.29:6.1.pli: Ahampi hi, bhante, yaññadeva devaputtaparisaṃ upasaṅkamiṃ, etadeva bahulaṃ saddaṃ suṇāmi:
sn2.29:6.1.eng: “For I too, sir, whenever I go to an assembly of godlings, frequently hear the same terms of praise.”

sn2.29:6.3.pli: mahāpañño āyasmā, puthupañño āyasmā, hāsapañño āyasmā, javanapañño āyasmā, tikkhapañño āyasmā, nibbedhikapañño āyasmā, appiccho āyasmā, santuṭṭho āyasmā, pavivitto āyasmā, asaṃsaṭṭho āyasmā, āraddhavīriyo āyasmā, vattā āyasmā, vacanakkhamo āyasmā, codako āyasmā, pāpagarahī āyasmā sāriputto’ti.

sn2.29:6.4.pli: Kassa hi nāma, bhante, abālassa aduṭṭhassa amūḷhassa avipallatthacittassa āyasmā sāriputto na rucceyyā”ti?

sn2.29:7.1.pli: Atha kho susimassa devaputtassa devaputtaparisā āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti.
sn2.29:7.1.eng: While this praise of Sāriputta was being spoken, the godlings of Susīma’s assembly—uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness—displayed a rainbow of bright colors.

sn2.29:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato paṇḍukambale nikkhitto bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca;
sn2.29:8.1.eng: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.

sn2.29:8.2.pli: evamevaṃ susimassa devaputtassa devaputtaparisā āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti.
sn2.29:8.2.eng: In the same way, the godlings of Susīma’s assembly displayed a rainbow of bright colors.

sn2.29:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma nikkhaṃ jambonadaṃ dakkhakammāraputtaukkāmukhasukusalasampahaṭṭhaṃ paṇḍukambale nikkhittaṃ bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca;
sn2.29:9.1.eng: Suppose there was a pendant of Black Plum River gold, fashioned by a deft smith, well wrought in the forge. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate.
sn2.29:9.1.comm: Legend has it that on the slopes of Mount Meru grows the vast Jambu tree that gives the continent of India her name, “the land of the black plum tree”. The fruits of that tree are as big as elephants, and when they fall, their juice flows forth as a river named Jambu. The dried mud of that river yields gold nuggets whose unparalleled lustre is highly sought-after among the gods. This is that gold (Śiva Purāṇa 17.16–19).

sn2.29:9.2.pli: evamevaṃ susimassa devaputtassa devaputtaparisā āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti.
sn2.29:9.2.eng: In the same way, the godlings of Susīma’s assembly displayed a rainbow of bright colors.

sn2.29:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ osadhitārakā bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca;
sn2.29:10.1.eng: Suppose that  in the autumn the heavens were clear and cloudless. At the crack of dawn, the Morning Star shines and glows and radiates.

sn2.29:10.2.pli: evamevaṃ susimassa devaputtassa devaputtaparisā āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti.
sn2.29:10.2.eng: In the same way, the godlings of Susīma’s assembly displayed a rainbow of bright colors.

sn2.29:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṃ abbhussakkamāno sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ tamagataṃ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca;
sn2.29:11.1.eng: Suppose that in the autumn the heavens were clear and cloudless. As the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, shines and glows and radiates.

sn2.29:11.2.pli: evamevaṃ susimassa devaputtassa devaputtaparisā āyasmato sāriputtassa vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā uccāvacā vaṇṇanibhā upadaṃseti.
sn2.29:11.2.eng: In the same way, the godlings of Susīma’s assembly displayed a rainbow of bright colors.

sn2.29:12.1.pli: Atha kho susimo devaputto āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.29:12.1.eng: Then the godling Susīma spoke this verse about Venerable Sāriputta in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.29:13.4.eng: the seer shines in the Teacher’s praise!”

sn2.29:14.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ ārabbha susimaṃ devaputtaṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn2.29:14.1.eng: Then the Buddha replied to Susīma with this verse about Venerable Sāriputta:

sn2.29:15.4.eng: developed and well-tamed, he awaits his time.”
sn2.29:15.4.comm: For reading kālaṁ kaṅkhati bhāvito sudanto, see note in Bodhi, Connected Discourses.

sn2.3:1.2.pli: Atha kho māgho devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.3:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Māgha, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.3:1.2.comm: Māgha is one of the many names of Sakka. It’s a taddhita construction from magha in possessive sense meaning “bounteous one”, and is thus a synonym of Maghavā (SN 11.12:1.3).

sn2.3:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho māgho devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.3:1.3.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn2.3:2.1.eng: “When what is slain do you sleep at ease?
sn2.3:2.1.comm: The same question is at SN 11.21 under the name Sakka and epithet Vāsava.

sn2.3:2.2.eng: When what is slain is there no sorrow?

sn2.3:3.1.eng: “When anger’s slain you sleep at ease.

sn2.3:3.2.eng: When anger’s slain there is no sorrow.

sn2.3:3.4.eng: and a honey tip, O Smiter of the Constrictor.
sn2.3:3.4.comm: Vatrabhū is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit vṛtrahan, “slayer of the Constrictor”; this is the only time it appears in Pali. Vṛtra was a massive cobra whose defeat at the hands of Indra/Sakka was a primordial Vedic myth (eg. Rig Veda 1.32). Vṛtra, who was identified with wickedness (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.1.5.7), held the waters imprisoned. The release of the waters for the good of all is the primary symbol of Indra’s bounty.

sn2.3:3.5.eng: The noble ones praise its killing,

sn2.3:3.6.eng: for when it’s slain there is no sorrow.”
